thread.title: GM Sees Earnings Accelerating For Several Years FCAU AAPL GOOGL - Investors.com
thread.title_full: GM Sees Earnings Accelerating For Several Years FCAU AAPL GOOGL - Investors.com

author: yahoo
title: GM Sees Earnings Accelerating For Several Years FCAU AAPL GOOGL - Investors.com
text:
G eneral Motors (NYSE: GM ) pointed to strong third-quarter earnings as a sign that the automaker is poised for a multiyear run of faster growth. 
Excluding $1.5 billion in recall-related expenses, GM's Q3 earnings per share jumped 55% to $1.50, beating views for $1.18. Revenue fell 1% to $38.84 billion due to currency headwinds, but it topped the Wall Street consensus for $38.55 billion. 
Operating margin in the key North America region widened to 11.8% from 10.5% in Q2 and 9.5% a year earlier as cheap gasoline powered U.S. sales. North American deliveries climbed 5.2%, though China sales fell 4.2%.   View Enlarged Image 

"The third quarter was evidence of the earnings power of this company, as we continue to build on our track record for generating results and delivering on our financial commitments," said CFO Chuck Stevens in a statement. "We expect our earnings to accelerate in the next several years, with double-digit earnings per share growth." 
GM was up 5.2% on the stock market today , driving its stock back above its 200-day average and further above its 50-day. Rival Ford Motor (NYSE: F ) was up 1.6%, while Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (NYSE: FCAU ) was down 4%. 
GM's earnings report came a day after it named LG Electronics as an official supplier of its upcoming 200-mile range Bolt electric vehicle, elevating its rivalry with luxury EV maker Tesla Motors (NASDAQ: TSLA ). 
GM and LG originally began working together on EVs in August 2011, with LG supplying the batteries for the Chevy Volt plug-in hybrid. 
LG will make the Bolt's electric drive motor using a GM design. It will make other Bolt hardware such as an onboard charger, battery cells and pack, instrument cluster and infotainment system. 
GM affirmed this week that it plans to begin production of the Bolt, which would be the first ever U.S.-made mass-market EV, in late 2016. It's projected to cost about $30,000 after government rebates. 
Tesla CEO Elon Musk has said that production of the lower-cost, mass-market Model 3 sedan — a direct rival to the Bolt — will start production in fall 2017. 
GM is also said to be working on autonomous self-driving car technology , which is also on the drawing board for Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL ), Alphabet (NASDAQ: GOOGL ) -owned Google, Ford and others. 
Meanwhile, Italian luxury sports car maker Ferrari (NYSE: RACE ) was up about 10% Wednesday after raising $894.4 million with its initial public offering late Tuesday, pricing at high end of its estimated range. Ferrari remains majority owned by Fiat Chrysler.
